There were five serious adverse reactions—anaphylaxis, which is a life threatening condition—but at one in every 260,000 children that is a tiny incidence. I am pleased to say that all those children have successfully recovered. This is something that all of Australia can be proud of. It is an example of preventive health. It is an example of everyone working together to achieve a fantastic health outcome.

talk.start.para: —Order! I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the Rt Hon. Don McKinnon, MP, the New Zealand Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, and some New Zealanders who are part of his delegation. I should inform the House that we have also had in the gallery a parliamentary delegation from Japan. A number of members were fortunate enough to join up with them both yesterday evening and this morning. Through his Excellency the Ambassador I know the House would want us to extend to them notice of our pleasure in having them in our country.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. How does the minister justify the unfair impact of the government's tax legislation on young mothers? Why does your GST bite into family budgets with an increased cost for food and increased costs for over-the-counter health items, such as calcium and iron supplements, pain killers, baby formula, nappies and even pregnancy testing kits? What representations did the minister make to reduce the burden on young mothers?
—Mr Speaker—
—Order! It is entirely within the standing orders for the Prime Minister to respond to the question, and I invite him to do so.

—The taxation plan is the most pro-family taxation policy this country has ever seen. I am delighted that the new member asked me this question because only this morning I had the opportunity to launch a book co-authored by the honourable member for Menzies called Changing Australia . I commend it to the honourable member who asked the question. Indeed, I commend it to all honourable members because it traces some very important social, economic and demographic changes in our country.

answer.para: One of the things it traces is the appalling increase in the tax burden on families that has occurred over the last 20 or 30 years. It records that in the last 20 or 30 years the effective marginal tax rate on an individual has risen by something like 83 per cent but the effective marginal tax rate on families has risen by 360 per cent. That underlines the crying need in this country to have a government that will introduce tax measures to provide some relief to mothers and fathers for the costs of raising children. We did it with our family tax initiative before 1996 and we have done it again with our taxation plan introduced by the Treasurer yesterday. We are doing it in relation to private health insurance. The party that the honourable member represents is voting against a measure that will advantage millions of mothers around Australia—
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: on the subject of relevance, my question was directed to what representations the minister had made to reduce the burden on young mothers. If the Prime Minister is taking the question, then he ought to be responding on the question of what representations he received. If the answer was none, he should say so.

—Order! The member for Lalor will resume her seat. The question dealt with the whole matter of tax reform and the way it impacts on families and the Prime Minister is responding. So far as I am aware, except in extraordinarily traditional roles young mothers are regarded as part of families.

—I say this very seriously to the honourable member who has just come into this parliament: if the honourable member is interested in striking a blow for tax equity for young mothers, she should vote for our private health insurance rebate. If she is interested in striking a blow for tax equity generally, she should vote for the coalition's taxation plan, which produces the greatest measure of taxation justice Australian mothers and Australian families have seen in the last 30 years.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Community Services. The minister would be aware that today is the International Day of People with a Disability. Minister, what has the government done to assist people with disabilities and to celebrate their abilities?

—May I thank the member for Dunkley for his question. I recognise the particular interest that he takes in the welfare of his constituents with disabilities, particularly employers who give young and older people with disabilities an opportunity to make a meaningful contribution to the workplace. I acknowledge that today the member has from his electorate in the gallery employers such as BTR Automotive and Woorinyan Employment Services. They are among the large group of people who assembled in the Great Hall today to commemorate the Prime Minister's Employer of the Year awards for people with disabilities. These awards—and they have been going now for the last nine years—recognise those employers who give opportunities to people with disabilities.

question.para: The remarkable thing that I am sure the honourable member for Dunkley and the honourable member for Mitchell and others who were present would have taken from that event was that the employers who are engaging people with disabilities do so because of their capacity to contribute to their workplace. They are good employees, they contribute to the profitability of their company and they are a practical demonstration that people with disabilities have talents and abilities to contribute to the nation as a whole.

On this day, when internationally we recognise people with disabilities, it is appropriate that we honour those employers who have made that particular effort. I acknowledge those employers, particularly the winner of the small business award, Benbro Electronics; the larger employer, HM Five-Star Engines; in the education sector, the South Metropolitan College of TAFE in Western Australia; and, the Commonwealth department that was acknowledged as doing the most in this area, the Department of Industry, Science and Resources. All of those people demonstrate to others that people with disabilities can contribute to the work force.

That is not all this government has done. It has signed the new agreement with the states for disability services, for the first time providing a common commitment to disability services and providing more funds than were ever provided under the previous government—a major boost in funding for people with disabilities. Today I announced the fulfilment of another coalition election promise to provide an additional $15 million of targeted assistance for ageing carers, those people who have the responsibility for, and who have been concerned as they grow older about their dependants with disabilities and what their future might be. These grants to all of the Australian states will help provide targeted assistance to those people.

Since July 1996, more than 20,000 new job seekers with disabilities have received assistance from our employment services network. So this government has an outstanding record in assisting people with disabilities. We particularly acknowledge those in the community—those carers and those employers—who recognise, and who help to celebrate today, the contribution of people with disabilities to our community.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Marriages and Funerals

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Treasurer. I seek clarification of an aspect of your goods and services tax bills. Is it the case that some marriage services will be subject to a GST and others will not? It is the case that some funeral services will be subject to a GST and others will not? By what reasonable criteria do you intend to distinguish between those fundamental family occasions which your government believes should be taxed and those that should not?

—The government's tax plan lists religious services as being GST free. I am sure the honourable member would approve of that. That means that, where churches or any religion so defined—it does not have to be a church—is delivering a service which is an integral part of that religious belief, it will be GST free. There will be no input taxes on it. They get all their input taxes back and they will not be paying any tax on outputs.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation. Minister, are you aware of the recent development of any financial markets' trading products and, if so, how these developments help Australia become a leading financial centre in the Asia-Pacific region?

—This is good news for Australia in a good news week. Apart from the national accounts figures that came out yesterday, apart from the 25 basis point drop in cash rates and apart from the introduction of structural change to our tax legislation by the Treasurer yesterday, I would like to advise the House that the Sydney Futures Exchange and Dow Jones, which is one of the world's largest business and financial publishers, have agreed to launch in the second quarter of next year a new index series known as APELS, Asia-Pacific Extra Liquid Series. It will be known as APELS around the world.

answer.para: This means that a funds manager sitting at her desk in New York will be able to trade index-linked products in Australia in real time. It means funds managers can buy and sell those products linked to, for example, the Hong Kong Stock Exchange or Japanese equities. They can trade them sitting at their desks in New York, London or Chicago. That will potentially extend to a wide range of products across the Asia-Pacific region. Obviously, funds managers around the world will have access to that.

Initially, this product will cover Hong Kong and Japan, but it is an exciting development for Australia because it opens the doors to massive amounts of international funds that will come through funds managers around the world. It will also trade on regional financial interests, not just Australian financial interests. Importantly, it provides an opportunity for international banks to base their operations in Australia, to run a single clearing account to access markets around the Asia-Pacific region. That means more jobs for more Australians.

This comes about through no small amount of effort. It comes because Australia has leading-edge world technology. It comes because we have better and simpler corporate law reform. It comes because we have a stable and growing economy. It comes because we have an innovative and sophisticated work force. It comes, most importantly, because of our commitment to a 21st century taxation system.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. At what point does a minister standing there reading a statement become a ministerial statement rather than an answer to a question?
—There is no point of order. The minister is responding to a question and the answer is entirely relevant to the question.

—On the point of order: are you disagreeing with former Speaker Sinclair's ruling that ministers should not be able to come into this chamber and read their answers and that the only reference they can make is in terms of quotes from documents? That is a clear ruling that former Speaker Sinclair made. I thought you had indicated on a previous occasion that you were going to adopt it.

—There is absolutely nothing in the standing orders that prevents a minister from reading a reply if he so desires. I happen to consider it inappropriate for a minister to read a reply. If he were to do so in detail, I would draw his attention to the fact that he was doing so.
—He's doing it!
—I will determine whether or not the level to which the reply is being read is appropriate. There is nothing in the standing orders that makes your point of order in any way valid.

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: I am amazed at that ruling in light of former Speaker Sinclair's ruling. Standing order 101, which sets down a process for ministerial statements, makes it quite clear that this process is out of order. He made that ruling on 4 March 1998 in Hansard at page 394. We request that you uphold that correct ruling.
—I have given my ruling and I call the minister.
—The opposition does not want to hear this good news.
—You are reading—you are looking down!

—I am looking down because I cannot stand looking at you. Dow Jones chose Australia over other regional financial centres, including Hong Kong and Singapore. Dow Jones chose Australia because of all that we offer and all that we will offer in the future. They are investing in Australia and Australian jobs. What it is going to bring to Australia is billions of tradeable dollars every day, every week and every year. That is good news for Australian jobs.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that the paper the minister was reading from be tabled.
—He wasn't reading!
—Was the minister reading?
—No way!

—I want to ask the next question. Before I do, I want to have that ruling clarified. Are you saying that if a minister asserts he was not actually reading but was only referring to a document he no longer has to table it?

—It is not necessary for me to offer any further explanation. Out of the respect I have for the member for Fraser, I will indicate that from the vantage point of the chair it was perfectly obvious that the minister could not have been reading from a document that in fact had four lines on it.
—He turned three pages. We saw him from here.
—I have ruled. I do not expect to have to enter into a debate with anybody in the chamber. I do not expect to have the member for Hotham engage in some other derisive remarks.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Marriages and Funerals

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Treasurer and, it follows by that, the member for Franklin. Having now indicated that weddings and funerals conducted by religious services are GST free, why are you proposing to not treat those conducted by civil celebrants in the same manner?

—The government determined in its policy that religious services would be GST free. That was the policy that we put to the Australian electorate and it is the policy that we are going to enact. In the last election, this government put out a detailed policy. We said to the Australian public, `If you want tax reform, vote this government back and we will enact it.' This is a government which seeks to do no more than fulfil all of its election pledges. That is why the Labor Party is so at odds on the particular issue. The Labor Party has never come across a government that wanted to actually deliver promises before.

answer.para: We remember the 1993 election when the Labor Party said, `No GST', and then hiked every wholesale sales tax after the election. We remember when the Labor Party said that it would cut income taxes.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. There is a very obvious question of relevance, apart from your previous ruling about scorn and derision which led you to comment to the member for Hotham but not refer to the Treasurer. I also wish to raise with you the question of relevance. On both those grounds, it seems that the Treasurer is wildly out of order.
—I call the Treasurer and ask him to come back to the question.

—I do. The point I make is that this government is implementing its policy and that that is our policy. The point I am also making is that the Labor Party is engaged in one effort in this parliament. It is engaged in an effort to try to make a government break its promise to the Australian people.

answer.para: This government puts out a policy and it asks to be elected. It comes back into this parliament, and it seeks to legislate it. To the Labor Party, this is some kind of novel proposition. It is a novel proposition. Before the 1993 election, the Labor Party said that it would cut taxes, but it did not. It said that it would not hike indirect taxes and it did. This government put out a policy in relation to income tax cuts and in relation to the goods and services tax and this government intends to implement them in full.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Many constituents in my electorate of Groom have raised concerns about the decision by the previous Labor government to close the analog mobile phone system by the year 2000. Would the minister outline to the House what the government is doing to ensure that regional residents are not disadvantaged by the proposed phase-out of the analog phone network?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. The short answer is that the government has been working very hard to overcome and untangle the mess left behind by the member for Dobell's appalling decision in 1992 to enter into contractual arrangements which clearly discriminated against the needs of rural and regional Australians, who, above all Australians, need access to top-quality telecommunications technologies and corridors.

answer.para: The government is absolutely delighted to be able to say that we have reached agreement with the three existing mobile phone carriers—Telstra, Optus and Vodafone—to ensure that all areas of regional Australia will continue to enjoy services where they have them now. There will be a 12-month extension of the analog coverage until 31 December 2000, and that coverage will remain in place until there are alternatives available.

In short, this really means that regional Australians do not lose out as a result of the quite disastrous and appallingly ill-thought through decision that the member for Dobell entered into in 1992. We will be imposing licence conditions on Telstra, requiring it to replace the analog AMPS network with an alternative digital network which provides reasonably equivalent coverage. Telstra has recently announced that it will be introducing a technology known as CDMA to construct a new network which will completely replace the existing AMPS network in both city and country. I think this is testimony to the commitment and the effectiveness of the Howard-Fischer government in meeting the needs of rural and regional Australians.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Through you, I ask the minister to table the document from which he was reading.
—Was the minister reading from a document?
—Apart from referring to a couple of notes, no.
—There is no obligation on the minister to table that document.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Financial Services

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. Doesn't the definition of `financial supplies'—
—Reading!

—The member for Hotham will resume his seat. Members on my right must know that that cacophony of sound does not in any way assist the House or the Speaker. The member for Hotham not only has the call but is entitled to be heard in silence, and I call him.
—And I am happy to table this.
—The member for Hotham will not get to ask his question unless he proceeds straight to it.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. Doesn't the definition of `financial supplies' in your goods and services tax bill imposing 10 per cent on almost everything mean that credit unions will have to pay a GST on the sorts of financial services that they outsource, such as data processing and cheque clearing? Isn't it true that banks will not have to pay the same GST, because they perform most of these activities in-house? How will this inequitable imposition of the GST assist the competition between credit unions and banks that you are so keen to encourage?

—I think I answered this question earlier in the week, making the point that credit unions will be treated the same as any other financial institution and will be under the same tax treatment. I also made the point earlier in the week that this problem so-called only arises because it was only when this government legislated that credit unions got the right to issue cheques. The way you solved the problem of credit unions was banning them from putting out cheques.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. This went to the question of the definition under his bill which treats them effectively differently.

—The member for Hotham will resume his seat. The chair is, in fact, exercising a good deal more latitude than the standing orders allow on these questions on tax reform. The obligation is on the Treasurer to answer the question in principle without specific reference to the legislation. I call the Treasurer.
—As I said, the treatment is precisely the same for a credit union as it is for a bank. It is precisely the same for any financial service provider. But I go on and make this point.
—You go on and on and on.
—You have had a bad week, haven't you?
—The Treasurer will return to the question, and the members for Prospect and Hotham will contain themselves.

—The only reason the question arises as to how you would treat cheques issued by credit unions is that this government, for the first time in Australian history, gave credit unions the right to issue cheques. They did not have it in 1983 or 1984 or 1985 or 1986 or 1987 or 1988 or 1989 or 1990—he is counting with me.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Can he stop his Thespian performance and answer the question about the differential treatment—
—The member for Hotham will resume his seat. I was interrupting the Treasurer and I call him now.
—I have concluded my answer.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Can the minister inform the House how today's announcement on the official recognition of foreign awards made to Australians during the Vietnam conflict will benefit Vietnam veterans in my electorate of Herbert?

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr BRUCE SCOTT
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Herbert for his question and I commend him on his enthusiasm for the concerns of veterans in his own electorate. I also note that tomorrow he is holding a presentation for veterans in his electorate. I would like to be with you but, unfortunately, I cannot. Today I announce—

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You don't want to hear about this, do you.
—The minister has the call; he will address his remarks through the chair.

—You don't want good news. Today I announce that Australian Vietnam veterans can now formally accept and wear South Vietnamese government and Cambodian government awards which were earned during their service in the Vietnam War. Records show that several hundred Australians received South Vietnamese and Cambodian awards during the Vietnam War, but at the time Australians were not allowed to officially accept or wear individual foreign awards.

answer.para: Under the government's foreign awards policy, there is now a mechanism whereby honours and awards, issued by a former foreign government which has ceased to exist, may be formally recognised and approved for wearing. This will allow those veterans to wear those awards and medals with great pride. This recognition has been sought by Vietnam veterans for a very long time, and it is hoped that more recipients and their families will apply for the official recognition of their service during the Vietnam War. I advise that applications are available from the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia, the Australian Army Training Team Vietnam Association, the RSL, the defence department and PM&C. This is good government policy brought forward by this government. It is going to be very much welcomed by the Vietnam veterans, and I hope it will be supported by both sides of this parliament.

talk.start.para: —I again direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer to the Treasurer's supposed concession to charities where they will not have to pay GST on sales of donated goods if they sell them for less than half the market price. Will there be inspectors examining the range of stock on sale by charities, item by item, to ensure that this concession is not being abused? And will this require separate documentation of every item received and sold by such charities? Aren't these currently tax exempt without this administrative nightmare?

—Before I call the Treasurer, I indicate that the question seeks more detail than I would have thought it reasonable to expect without abusing the anticipation rule. I invite the Treasurer to answer the question if he so desires.
—Well, I earnestly desire, Mr Speaker. The question of course starts from a false premise, as usual.
—Why is it?

—I will tell you why it is false. There are two exemptions: it does not apply in relation to donated second-hand goods; nor does it apply in relation to non-commercial sales, which are judged on either of two grounds—either 50 per cent less of the price or 50 per cent less of the cost.
—How do you determine 50 per cent?
—You said that there was a double test. It is an individual test on any one of those three grounds. That is the first point. The second point—
—I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. If we have now established that you have to determine a price, what policing mechanism is he going to have to insist upon it? That's the question.
—The member for Hotham will resume his seat and consider himself warned.
—He asks a question, you are in the middle of answering it, and so he asks a different one.
—The Treasurer will respond to the question.

—The question is wrong. In relation to charities the reason we put that test is that we think that, by and large—and I think there are reasonable grounds for this—most charities are honest. As a matter of fact, we do not think there is going to be any great problem with the Salvation Army cheating on the tax system.
—No, or the St Vincent de Paul.

—Or the St Vincent de Paul or the Catholic Church cheating on the tax system. I think that, by and large, you can trust the Catholic Church. You can trust the Anglican Church. I think that by and large you can trust the churches if they say they are engaging in non-commercial activities. But I suppose, if there is any evidence to the contrary—in the same way as if there is any evidence to the contrary in relation to all of the taxes that currently apply—you have a look at it. That is the way you do these things.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is the minister aware of the results of the national literacy tests conducted to date? What are the implications of these results for educational equality?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Kalgoorlie for his question. I am aware that results of the first tests against the national benchmark have been announced by the education minister in Western Australia. This is a very historic moment for Australian education, because for the first time we now have placed on the public record an assessment of the literacy standards of all students in one state in years 3 and 5 against an objective national standard. This standard has been established by this government in consultation with all the states and territories.

answer.para: For the first time, now all students in Australia have an opportunity to be brought up to the basic literacy level that will be required for them to continue successfully with their education. After 13 years of the previous government, there was no such standard in place. With regard to literacy, the Labor Party included a mere five lines within its education policy at the election. It was going to hand over the national literacy standards to the Australian Education Union.

The results of the Western Australian tests will be of interest to the House. Western Australia found that 20 per cent of all students were below the national standard. It found that 60 per cent of all indigenous students were below the national standard. I congratulate the Western Australian minister on being prepared to put this information on the public record in order to be honest with the Australian people and to indicate the determination of his government to finally address this problem once and for all. Literacy is the greatest social equity issue in education today. It falls to the coalition to address social justice issues in education which have been unaddressed for decades.

This government has committed an additional $112 million to literacy and numeracy standards in Australian schools. Today I announced that next year the government will be putting in place a National Indigenous Literacy Strategy within the national plan to ensure that educational equality is finally delivered to indigenous students in the shortest possible time, building on the excellent results of the strategic result projects that I announced earlier this year. We will be working to ensure that all Australians students—indigenous and non-indigenous—will reach the literacy levels by the end of year 3 in school that will enable them to continue successfully with their education. This will have a dramatic effect on the quality of schooling in Australia, the quality of the classroom experience, and is fundamental to addressing the tremendously difficult problem of youth unemployment.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Small Business

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Treasurer. Isn't your new 10 per cent GST going to create a compliance nightmare for Australia's 1.3 million small businesses, turning them into tax collectors? Can you confirm that administering the nightmare—
—Mr Speaker—
—The member for Blaxland shall resume his seat. I will allow him to continue, but I have a point of order.

—Mr Speaker, the Leader of the House has allocated 20 hours to debate the legislation. In that question there is no pretence of a request for specific clarification. It is an invitation to debate. Why would any of us contribute to the debate on the legislation if it has already been fully canvassed in question time?

—The member for Parramatta will resume his seat. The question is not inconsistent with other questions that have been allowed and, as ministers are aware, the way in which they answer the question determines the degree to which they in fact refer to the legislation.

—I will begin from the beginning again. Treasurer, isn't your new 10 per cent GST going to create a compliance nightmare for Australia's 1.3 million small businesses, turning them into tax collectors? Can you confirm that administering that nightmare will cost $1.3 billion for the first three years of the GST? Can the Treasurer inform the House of the number of new GST police that will be involved?
—The answer to the last part of the question is none, no police—strangely enough, no police.
—The Treasurer will respond through me.
—Mr Speaker, let me read for the member some of the advantages of a broadly based consumption tax:

answer.para: A broadly based consumption tax . . . would—
. provide much larger income tax cuts.
. reduce marginal tax rates . . . at all income levels . . .
. increase the tax take from people who continue to avoid or evade income tax.
. provide . . . revenue to enable a more generous benefit for wage and salary earners . . .
. enable the existing wholesale tax to be abolished . . .

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. The question asked was whether this tax was going to cost $1.3 billion, as the document the Treasurer released tends to indicate. We want to know that. We do not wish to hear him quoting from himself or anyone else.
—The member for Fraser will resume his seat. The Treasurer's reply, as you have in fact indicated, is consistent with the question and is entirely relevant.

—I read about the benefits that come from indirect tax reform from a book in fact written by a former member for Blaxland, Mr P.J. Keating. And, because I was reading, I table the document from which I was reading. I want to table a copy because it is the only original I have. I think they tried to destroy them down in the Treasury.
—The Treasurer will resume his seat. The Treasurer has tabled the document.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of comments in recent days about the growth prospects of the Australian economy? What are the implications of these comments?

—In reply to the honourable member for Fairfax, can I say to him that I am aware of statements made in recent days about the growth prospects of the Australian economy. I am also, as it happens, aware of some statements made about the growth prospects of the Australian economy in not so recent days. In fact, I follow comments about the growth prospects of the Australian economy, and I follow them particularly closely, as befits the discipline in my office, when they are made by the Leader of the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition over the last few months has made some very interesting comments about the growth prospects of the Australian economy. For example, on 22 July 1998, interviewed by Fran Kelly on Radio National, he had this to say:

answer.para: The growth that has come off in Australia over the last couple of years as a result of Costello's Budget, before the budgets before the Asian crisis hit us, has been entirely a product of their misplaced fiscal policy and nothing to do with the rest of the world.
That was not bad. Then on 27 September 1998 the Leader of the Opposition had this to say:
The problem is this, the Government took a baseball bat to growth, completely unnecessarily.

Some baseball bat, I have got to say! Some growth! I think you are thinking of the baseball bat that the voters of Queensland took to your predecessor. But on 18 November 1998 this is what he had to say:

A slowing down the pace of growth—yes. We have had that as a result of John Howard taking a baseball bat to the Australian economy immediately after he came into office and that now the Asian region crisis kicks in and that will slow our growth rates.

And so the list goes on. The reality is that month after month the Leader of the Opposition was predicting doom and gloom and despair and desperation. Now even the most stubborn critics of the Australian economy would have to acknowledge that we have turned in remarkable growth rates, for which the entire Australian community deserves a great deal of respect and thanks from the government. Can I, on behalf of the government, particularly thank my colleague the Treasurer for his contribution and the work he has done in relation to the stewardship of the economy.

I also record my gratitude to the Reserve Bank of Australia for the way in which it has managed the monetary policy of this country over the arrangement that was entered into between the government and the Reserve Bank when we came to office in 1996. In fact, the behaviour of the Reserve Bank of Australia is an object lesson in the conduct of monetary policy to central banks around the world.

But, in the face of all this evidence, the Leader of the Opposition is now starting to change his tack. Do you know what his tack now is? Having blamed the coalition for the last 2½ years for any kind of bad sign that might be around, now that there is unambiguous good news, what is the response of the Leader of the Opposition? The response of the Leader of the Opposition is to say that today's good news is really due to what Labor did before we were elected in 1996. That is an unbelievable performance. He is still saying it.

This is what he had to say. He said that, while Australia was not completely fireproofed for the Asian currency crisis, Labor could take some credit for helping shield the economy. Labor left us with a $10½ billion deficit. They opposed every attempt we made over the last 2½ years to correct their mess. They predicted gloom and despair. Every time we had good news, they talked the Australian economy down. They ran around and sent their emissary to Kyoto to try to undermine that greenhouse safe arrangement we made. The Leader of the Opposition allowed Senator Bolkus to ride over to UNESCO undermining the representations of the lawfully elected government of this country. That happens every time they get a chance.

They want the views of foreigners to destroy Australian jobs. As far as that great uranium mine in the Northern Territory is concerned, there are 1,000 Australian jobs, $12,000 million of export income and untold revenue to the federal Treasury. But what does the Labor Party want? They want that mine closed down. They want to close down Australian jobs. In office they neglected the national interests. In opposition they have not changed. I can only say that it has been a great week for the Australian economy. It has been a great week for the Australian national interest. But it has been a terrible week for the Australian Labor Party. Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I ask you a question based on the considerable concern on this side of the House regarding your continuing habit of making comments and assisting ministers as to how they might answer questions. I seem to recall that a few people here raised points of order about that when they were in opposition.
—The member for Fraser has the call and he is experienced enough to know better than to reflect on the chair.
—I am not reflecting; I am telling you that we have great concern about this, Mr Speaker. I want to ask you a question about it.
—I am prepared to hear the question of the member for Fraser.
—I want to know—and, I have to say, a lot of people on this side want to know as well—whether that habit of yours is going to continue and whether it reflects your view—
—I am prepared to hear the member for Fraser.
—Does this reflect your view that your role should be that of a commentator rather than a neutral presiding officer?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that the convention and the practice in this chamber is that members are entitled to ask you questions about the matters within your administration. It is inappropriate for the member for Fraser, or any other member, under the guise of a question, to get up and attack or make inferences about your speakership. That is totally inappropriate. I invite you to make it clear that you will not take questions of that sort again in the future.
—I wish to inform the House that I have no intention of changing any of the habits I have exhibited in the chair over the last two weeks.

—Mr Speaker, my question to you relates to standing order 84, which provides that no member may interrupt another member whilst speaking unless to call attention to a point of order or to raise a matter of privilege or something like that. I have noticed the increasing tendency of members of the opposition, particularly the member for Hotham, to rise during question time while a minister is accurately and effectively answering a question and interrupt the minister in his answer—not even under the guise of raising a point of order.

—The member for Lyne will hear this in silence. The member for Indi has not sought the call on the basis of a point of order. If that is offering a commentary, bad luck. That is the state of play. The member for Indi has the call in a question to me.
—The member for Hotham, particularly, is increasingly coming to his feet whilst a minister is answering a question, not even saying, `I raise a point of order.'
—I presume the member for Indi is coming to a question to me.

—Yes, sir. He is launching into a denial and rebuttle of the minister's answer. I ask you, Mr Speaker, whether that continuing and increasing poor practice is bad for the House and should not be permitted under standing order 84.
—The member for Indi will resume his seat. The Speaker will continue to determine who does and does not get the call.

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. After your admonition to the opposition about the member for Fraser's question to you, the member for Prospect very clearly called out that you were biased. I ask her to withdraw that statement.
—I did not hear the member for Prospect. She has said nothing this day that has offended me.

—Mr Speaker, I have a question to you in respect of the role that you exhibit in this place as keeper of the Hansard . In Hansard of yesterday at page 939 where the record shows that at approximately 7.48 p.m. there was a division in this House in which the Deputy Speaker was in the chair there seems to have been an omission. There was a check of the tape made because a number of members of the parliament had made comment at the time.

question.para: The tape has indicated Mr Deputy Speaker said, `I think the noes have it.' The honourable member for Hunter, Mr Fitzgibbon, said, `The ayes have it.' Mr Deputy Speaker said, `No, they don't . . . You don't want the member for Hunter to be able to move his amendment. That is the impact of what you are saying. Well, okay, all right. I will accept what you want. Division required. You're absolutely mad. Ring the bells for four minutes.'

My question to you is that if, in fact, those words, which I think many people in this place heard last night, form part of the record, why aren't they in Hansard? Secondly, in picking up a point the member for Fraser asked, is it going to be the intention of the Deputy Speaker to make comment or simply just to adjudicate on the standing orders in this place as well?

talk.start.para: —What the member for Cunningham knows better than most people in the chamber is that the Hansard he has in his hand at this stage is a proof Hansard . I will check the record and come back to him. I was not in the chamber obviously at that time. I did notice, however, from where I was seated that the chamber was in some turmoil, so it may have been difficult to get an accurate record of precisely what was happening.

—Mr Speaker, during question time when we observed that the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation was reading his response to the question, I asked you to rule on the question of ministers reading. In your response, you observed that the minister could not have been reading because he had only one piece of paper with four lines on it. It was very clear to us on this side of the House that he was on to page 3 by the time we got to this discussion. So I am asking you, Mr Speaker, will you view a tape taken from this side of the House and, if our observation is correct, will you rethink the ruling that you gave?

—In response to the member for Burke, I have sat on that side out of the House for longer than I care to remember, as everyone will understand. In that time I have watched a number of ministers read answers to questions. There is no standing order that forbids them from reading answers to questions, so I have no intention of referring to the TV tape record of the proceedings.

—Mr Speaker, my question to you relates to comments that were made by yourself during question time in respect of a question asked by the honourable member for Lalor. The comments that you made were to the effect of: `So far as I am aware, except in extraordinarily non-traditional roles, young mothers are regarded as part of families.' In the context of a question about the harm a GST will cause to young mothers, don't your comments on your personal experience of women's lives run the risk—
—Withdraw!
—Order! Members on my right! The member for Gellibrand is a new member.

—In the context of a question asked by the member for Lalor about the harm a GST will cause young mothers, don't your comments on your personal experience of women's lives run the risk, perhaps not intentionally, of stigmatising the 467,000 single mothers in this country?

—The member for Gellibrand will resume her seat. I have rarely in my time in this place faced as offensive a suggestion. There is nothing in my ruling that in any way reflected unfavourably on any young mothers at any time. I was merely endeavouring to make the point that the traditional family is no longer a husband, a wife and two children.
